DOC.TEXT: The stock market showed a broad loss again today amid persistent worries about the future course of the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 56.10 points in the past two sessions, dropped 10.46 to 2,687.07 by noontime on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 333 up, 1,044 down and 489 unchanged. Analysts said the latest economic reports from the government hadn't done much to pull the market out of its recent slide, induced to a great extent by worries about the real estate market and mortgage debt. The Labor Department reported that the consumer price index rose 0.4 percent in November, or at an annual rate of 4.9 percent. That appeared to put a new obstacle before any fresh moves by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Separate government figures showed a 4.7 percent decline in housing starts last month. Brokers said that left stocks in the grip of recession fears and of talk that a slump in business conditions might be exacerbated by a weak market for homes and other real-estate properties. A few recently depressed mortgage and regional banking stocks staged a rebound. Federal National Mortgage rose | to 31}, and Bank of New England gained ] to 7~. But most other bank stocks remained on the defensive. Citicorp fell ~ to 26; Chase Manhattan { to 31]; J.P. Morgan } to 39~, and Chemical Banking { to 28}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.29 to 188.88. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.64 at 368.22. Volume on the Big Board came to 99.24 million shares at noontime, up from 74.84 million at the same point Monday.
